title: Confidential Magazine

content:
At the end of August - almost 29 years to the day since I begun my career in the games industry - I resigned and entered into what I’ve been describing as “retirement”. The quotes indicating that I haven’t quite decided what form it will take.
Quitting had been on my mind for a while, in that typically vague wishy washy “oh, I dunno - sometime in the future” way, but a surprise decision by company execs to pursue a business partnership I felt was deeply unethical and problematic suddenly brought the need to make a change front and centre with a real jolt. C’est la vie - I have zero regrets and feel so much better for it.
While I’m unsure I have the energy to return to a games industry utterly unrecognisable from the one I entered in 1995, I find myself more fascinated than ever by how we experience and engage with the world around us, and the role technology can play in encouraging and facilitating this. 12+ years of work and research in Augmented Reality, Spatial Computing and geographic/location based experiences have shown me that the Black Mirror-esque “AI” powered AR glasses future pushed by the likes of meta is not the way we should be heading. There is a different future with tech respecting the user and environment while effectively getting out of the way that - in my opinion - is far more interesting and exciting.
Over time I’ve cobbled together a document I aspirationally refer to as my manifesto (if only it were coherent enough to qualify as one) which brings together a whole range of fields I feel are interesting and connected. As I continue to ruminate on and explore this space, I hope to post occasional rambles about it all.
Or I may just sit on the couch and re-watch “Columbo” episodes…
title: A Sudden Change of Plans

content:
My little nook on the internet where I blat down ramblings on my current projects. Well, that’s the theory. In practice I’m an exceptional procrastinator.
The main things occupying my noggin these days are to do with psychogeography, perception, field recordings, nature, maps, philosophy, art and generally pondering how we experience the world around us. I also love retro computers/gaming, and the demoscene (AMIGAAA).
title: Welcome to Ziggurat

content:
News #Editor Andy Nuttall reckoned this issue was “more fruitsome and lovely than ever”.
A new contender for acquiring Commodore entered the ring: Escom, who had put in a bid for £5 million. The Commodore UK team downplayed this saying the bid was low and their own offer was still favourite. Meanwhile, Escom had bought out failed UK high street shop chain Rumbelows.
Retailer Silica were staying the course with their Amiga sales and launched a new CD32 bundle.
Battery maker Duracell had produced “The Duracell Challenge” - a free game which they hoped would “harness piracy” to spread… there was prize money at stake and apparently every consumer who provided the game to an eventual winner would get a share. The interesting bit was that it was developed by The Mounties, who had been setup by none other than Mel Croucher (of Automata/Pi Man fame) to focus on interactive advertising. Oh, and it was PC only at the time of publication.
The UK was about to get a new terrestrial TV channel in the form of Channel 5, but the frequency could cause interference with Amiga RF cables.
The Monopolies and Mergers Commission slapped Nintendo and Sega on the wrists for: “… setting high prices on software and unrealistically low prices on hardware, charging third parties too much to manufacture the games, wielding too much power over other publishers, outlawing rental when they shouldn’t and putting complex electronics into consoles to stop others producing software for them.” And those stern words were the extent of the punishment.
“Coala” was a new helicopter flight sim from Empire.
Kompart Krew had provided some teasers of a bunch of new games they were publishing for the Amiga: “Tower of Souls”, “Chess Through the Ages” (unreleased?), “Evil’s Doom” (developed by Croteam, unreleased) and “Turbo Trax”.
A “rather raw-looking press release” from Cobra Developments heralded the release of “For The Love Of Money” for the CD32 which promised a “perfect balance of arcade action and adventure.” (unreleased?)
Games industry trade show ECTS drew record crowds (8,500 over the three days), though the only stands with new Amiga wares were Team 17, Black Legend and Renegade. At the ECTS awards Bullfrog cleaned up, with “Magic Carpet” winning best home computer game and most original title of the year.
Buried in the ECTS news was mention of Team 17 striking a deal with Ocean to provide more funds for development.
London’s Science Museum had a new exhibition which would allow visitors to experience the “information superhighway”.
A study by Plymouth University psychologist Mark Griffiths concluded that games could be beneficial for kids with “brain disorders, behavioural problems and arm injuries.” Apparently they could also cure “chronic nose pickers”.
The Spotlight Show which focussed on the Amiga was going ahead at London’s Novotel hotel on June 10th and 11th. Though the fact that Commodore were listed as one of the exhibitors did raise eyebrows.
US Gold’s budget label KIXX were releasing a new batch of re-releases, including “Speedball”, “Xenon 2”, “Robocod”, “Tennis Cup 2” and “Thunderblade”.
Features #On this month’s two cover disks:
“Gloom” Black Magic (demo) “Platman” PD “Sensible World of Soccer Update Disk” Sensible Software Getting the in-depth Work In Progress treatment this month:
“Gloom” Black Magic “Fears” M.A.N.Y.K./Bomb Software “ViroCop” Graftgold/Renegade “Leading Lap” Kellion “X-Fighter” Thalion UK (apparently unreleased, but I think this did get out somehow) “Brutal: Paws of Fury” Software Sorcery/Gametek “Chaos Engine 2” Bitmap Brothers/Renegade - the fifth and final instalment, for reals. PD games covered:
“Poker Mania” 90% “Scavenge” 90% “Zxam Spectrum Emulator” 80% “Charlie Chatter” 62% “Cyber Games” 23% Gremlin’s PR Manager, Steven Michael Andrew McKevitt, was subjected to the “Eliza Files” interview.
Notable Reviews # “Pizza Tycoon” MicroProse - 88% “There are lots of silly things that keep PT from just becoming a repetitive management game, and if you hire managers for your restaurants you don’t have to keep worrying about ordering enough tomatoes once you get involved in challenges and espionage.” “Exile (AGA)” Audiogenic - 86% “The game scores highly in the ‘sheer fun’ department, with lots of action and reward. I wouldn’t be surprised to see Exile receive a varied range of scores, as it nostalgically scores well, can also impress the first time player, but may fall when compared to the original or modern-day competitors.” Charts # “Super SkidMarks” Acid “Sensible World of Soccer” Sensible Software/Renegade “Pinball Illusions” Digital Integration/21st Century
title: This month in... The One '95

content:
News #The One had had a bit of a facelift with the Contents page getting a re- design, along with various sections getting re-labelled.
The big news for the month was that Commodore UK had announced a new Amiga: the A1(M). The specs included “32 megabytes of RAM, a 1 gigabyte hard drive, 32-bit graphics card, 64-bit processor, 8x speed CD-ROM drive”. And of course it was The One’s April Fools.
Thalion had hit on their hands with “A320 Airbus” which had shifted over 250,000 copies, so it was no surprise they were working on the follow-up, “Approach Trainer”.
The highly anticipated (perhaps a slight exaggeration) “Street Fighter” movie had arrived and The One’s critical verdict? “Poo”.
“Kung Fu bunnies, kick-boxing foxes, and wrestling bears” featured in Gametek’s new beat-’em-up, “Brutal: Paws of Fury”.
Some bloke named Steve Minton had started a new user group for fans for “Frontier”. Interested people were to mail him their save games and some “Frontier” tips.
I guess getting a mention as a sign there was still a little life in our favourite machine, retailer Silica had put out its new Amiga catalogue.
“Gloom” looked like it might provide a decent Doom-ish experience.
Impressions reckoned their “Ultimate Soccer Manager” would be “the last word in football strategy games”.
While Microprose hadn’t been keen on the idea of bringing any new titles to the Amiga, they were porting “Colonization”.
Gametek had acquired the licence to “The X-Files”.
The One acknowledged the passing of Lt Commander Sir Marshall George Clitheroe Warmington, 3rd Bart, aged 84. Why? Because he was apparently the first person in the 20th century to be called “Pants”….
The National Museum of Computer and Video games opened… in St Louis… in the US…
Probe Software changed its name to Probe Entertainment.
A drop in general retail sales during January were blamed on the National Lottery.
Warner Interactive Entertainment followed its acquisition of Renegade by signing Sensible Software for their next three titles and an option on every following game. They had been up against Virgin, which would still publish “Sensible Golf”.
Features #On this month’s two cover disks:
“X-Fighter” Thalion (demo) (full game was never released) “Flight of the Amazon Queen” Renegade Sensible Software’s Jon Hare popped up in the Letters section to answer a slew of “Sensible World of Soccer” related questions & gripes from readers.
A light hearted ratings roundup of beat’em up fighter fashions.
Microprose PR Manager Jason Dutton was subjected to the “Eliza Files” interview (first half questions asked by a journo, second half him conversing with software therapist Eliza).
Getting the in-depth Work In Progress treatment this month:
“Super Street Fighter 2” Freestyle Games/US Gold “Lost Eden” Cryo (unreleased) “Player Manager 2” Steve Screech/Anco “Chaos Engine 2” Bitmap Brothers/Renegade (Part 4.. the penultimate?) “Baldies” Creative Edge/Gametek (unreleased) “The Speris Legacy” Binary Emotions/Team 17 “Final Over” Team 17 (unreleased) PD Games covered:
“Zaxxon” 78% “Bubble Trubble” 89% “Aquanaut” 93% “Charr” 77% “Graphic Adventure Creator (inc. Lethal Formula)” 88% Notable Reviews # “Skidmarks 2” Acid Software - 88% “…. apart from some neat additions tacked on to the main game, this could actually be Skidmarks. Where it does score brownie points, though, is with the sheer madness of it all.” “Dawn Patrol” Rowan/Empire - 81% “Still, the fact is that Rowan’s engine is a good one, and on balance, and after much split-arseing about with my conscience, I reckon Dawn Patrol is Rowan’s best yet, especially if you don’t own either of the earlier games.” “Ambermoon” Thalion - 84% “Great areas of the screen judder past as you struggle to shift about from one room to the other, spoiling what should be an exciting and spooky aspect of Ambermoon. Once you get used to the poor scrolling, though, the underlying game appears and reassures you that your money wasn’t wasted.” Charts # “Sensible World of Soccer” Sensible Software/Renegade “Pinball Illusions” Digital Illusions/21st Century “FIFA Soccer” EA
title: This month in... The One '95

content:
News #Despite some recent colossal flops at the box office (“Mario Brothers” and “Double Dragon”) it seemed the success of “Street Fighter” was enough for Hollywood to take another stab it with “Mortal Kombat”. The only “big names” attached to it were Christopher Lambert and Talisa Soto (a Bond girl in “Licence to Kill”). Unknown Paul Anderson was to direct. Elsewhere there were rumours of movies based on “Doom” and “Myst”.
Ocean’s budget label Hit Squad was adding a new title each month through June: “Jurassic Park”, “Space Hulk”, “Cannon Fodder” and “Syndicate”.
Thalion’s “Ambermoon” for the CD32 was finally making its way to the UK after initially only being released in continental Europe.
A rather surprising book tie-in was being written. Jim Murdoch’s “Rise of the Robots” would be published by Penguin.
There was a compatibility list for CD32 games running on the Zappo A1200 CD drive.
The One received an unusual demand from ICE Software regarding their upcoming “Akira” game. They were not releasing review copies to journos “until our forthcoming trip to the USA”. However, they had already supplied The One with a copy and stipulated that a review could only be printed if the score was higher than 80%. There was no review in this issue.
Gremlin invested in a motion capture system from Motion Analysis. Meanwhile they were to release an add on for “Premier Manager 3”. The “Premier Manager Multi-Edit System” would allow players to make their own updates to the league.
Canada’s DEM Software were having a crack at a “Doom” clone with “Angst”.
It’d been nearly a year since stocks of new Amigas ran out and The One summarised what kind of prices you could expect if you wanted to pick up a used one.
Grandslam were working on a new platformer, “Ruffian”.
The One, in a clear state of frustration, refused to even attempt to try to write up “news” regarding the fate of Commodore.
Electronic Arts acquired Bullfrog for a cool $45 million. The US game giant insisted Bullfrog would maintain complete control and even be able to license some titles to other publishers.
Ultramind’s “RelaxPlus” claimed to enable thought control of games via a bio- sensor which “attaches to a player’s skin”.
TV Gladiator Shadow’s alleged “alarming” cocaine habit forced Gremlin to scramble to replace him with Hunter in their ad campaign for “Shadow Fighter”.
Team 17 were apparently working on a cricket game which looked somewhat like Sensible’s recent titles (unreleased).
Features #On this month’s two cover disks:
“Valhalla: Before the War” Vulcan (demo) “FIFA Soccer” Electronic Arts (demo) An interview with Kiwi game devs Acid Software.
Despite industry body ELPSA’s introduction of a voluntary ratings system for games, the UK government’s new legislation meant games would now be subject to the same way of classification as videos. The One investigated what this would mean for gamers.
Games getting in-depth Work in Progress articles this month:
“Worms” Team 17 “Alien Breed 3D” Team 17 “Chaos Engine 2” The Bitmap Brothers/Renegade (Part 3…) “Pussies Galore” Amber Developments/Team 17 (unreleased) “Frontier 2: First Encounters” Frontier Developments/Gametek (unreleased) PD games reviewed:
“Blast ’em!” 87% “Island” POO (yes, that was the rating) “Captain Carnage” 51% “Punter v2.2” 79% “Carwars” 30% Notable Reviews # “ATR” Team 17 - 85% “When you first buy ATR, you’ll find it annoying, but when you get into the game, it just gets better and better. Highly polished, well-presented, nicely-executed. Great.” “Roketz” The Farm/Exclusive PD (A1200) - 85% “You might need a few goes against the computer in order to get the hang of things but, my dears, it’s got to be said, Roketz is a lovely little two-player game.” “Speedball 2” The Bitmap Brothers/Renegade (CD32) - 83% “If I was looking at this as an Update, there wouldn’t really be too much to comment on, but the new music is superb, and the inclusion of more commentator samples and crowd effects boosts the atmosphere considerably.” “The Complete Chess System” Oxford Soft - 80% “If you don’t have an interest in chess but think you might like to have a bash one day, this is the sort of package that will be a valuable from beginner level right up to when you consider yourself a real chess old master.” Charts # “Sensible World of Soccer” Sensible Software/Renegade “FIFA Soccer” EA “Theme Park” EA
title: This month in... The One '95

content:
News #Andy Nuttall officially took over the Editor role.
If you thought that the future of Commodore would be sorted out by this month, then you were sorely mistaken. The end did seem in sight (something that had been said for nearly a year), with only Commodore UK and US-based CEI remaining in the running. Meanwhile retailers were getting frustrated with the lack of new stock. With that said, apparently 82% of stores surveyed were keen to continue selling the machines (if they were provided some to sell…).
The UK government warned game publishers that they would now be required to submit all titles for certification.
A player’s guide to “Lemmings” was on the way from Kuma.
Ocean had grown tired of clamouring for attention in the saturated end of year market and decided to space out new releases throughout the year, starting with “TFX”.
Research by Professor Stephen Heppeli showed that playing games improved the problem solving skills of children.
The World of Amiga had proven a success, with an estimated 5,000 visitors/punters on each of the three days. Commodore UK had held back 250 A1200s just for the show, and all were sold within the first morning.
“Sensible Golf” had been delayed until April.
It looked like the days of the medium software houses may be coming to an end, with the big media companies entering the market and making acquisitions. In order to compete, the Ocean took investment from French media giant Chargeurs, Virgin from Blockbuster, US Gold went public and Gremlin was contemplating a similar move.
The game industry police (?) arrested Robert Butler, the sysop of the Krypt BBS. He was fined £500 and had all his gear confiscated.
“Sensible World of Soccer” was triumphant in the Christmas sales charts, moving 50,000 copies across Europe on just the first day. “Rise of the Robots” and “Mortal Kombat II” were next in line. Ocean sold 20,000 copies each of “Jungle Strike” and “PGA European Tour Golf”.
Matthew Brailsford was crowned “Premier Manager 2” Manager of the Year.
The band Genesis invested in Alternative Software’s CD startup, Quicksilver, which had started releasing discs for the CD32.
Elsewhere another musician, Feargal Sharkey, began working for record label ESP who were producing “interactive” albums.
The British Computer Society created an Internet site to provide information on tailor-made peripherals catering for users with disabilities.
A VR headset which allowed disabled users to experience public transport in order to build up their confidence had been developed by Division.
Interactive was a new games focussed TV show appearing on Channel One, the UK’s first cable news network.
Technics released the SC-VC10 - the world’s first VideoCD compatible minisystem - in the US.
Empire software were to produce a new compilation pack, “Award Winners Platinum”, consisting of “Frontier: Elite 2”, “Civilisation” and “Lemmings”.
“Manchester United: The Double” was the follow up to Krisalis’s “Manchester United: Premier League Champions”.
Beat’em up “Elfmania” was to begin appearing as a comic strip in Manga fanzine “Animenia”.
Features #On this month’s two cover disks:
“Marvin’s Marvellous Adventure” 21st Century (A1200) (demo) “Shadow Fighter” Gremlin (demo) In a slightly odd take on the interview format, Digital Image Design’s Nick Clarkson first sat down for a chat with one of the staff and was then subjected to a session with Eliza.
Games getting the in-depth Work In Progress treatment this month:
“Boo!” The Conversion Company/Microprose (unreleased) “Chaos Engine 2” Bitmap Brothers/Renegade (part 2) “Legends” Krisalis “Master Axe” Millennium “High Seas Trader” Impressions Reviewed in PD Zone:
“Maze Madness” 64% “Trick or Treat” 86% “Martial Spirit” 80% “Wheelie” 62% “De-Luxe Galaga” 95% Notable Reviews # “Shadow Fighter” NAPS/Gremlin - 91% “For someone wanting a Street Fighter 2 copy, this has everything; right from the slow-motion knock-out strikes to the ‘Round One. Fight!’ announcer. The special moves, in-game tunes, spot effects, and animations (with that stunning background parallax!) really just add more icing to the icing to the icing, leaving you wondering why no one has done this before.” “Bloodnet” Gametek - 84% “Overall, I liked this game a lot, and if you have the necessary hardware (one for game-starved A4000 owners), like adventure games, and are familiar with cyber-speak, buy it.” (Apparently running from floppy required 28 disk swaps to reach the game…) “Flink” Psygnosis - 87% “Flink, has no such option [in game saves, passwords etc], and so while playing through the game is an absolute joy, dying and having to return to the beginning each time soon becomes tedious.” “On the Ball: League Edition” Ascon/Daze - 87% “I can’t score this version as highly as I did with the first game simply because the WC edition was a revelation. This, however, is, and though still clever, is more of a data package than a sequel or alternative.” Charts # “Sensible World of Soccer” Sensible Software/Renegade “Mortal Kombat II” Acclaim “Theme Park” Bullfrog/EA
title: This month in... The One '95

content:
News #Apparently the higher ups at EMAP were putting pressure on The One to cut back on pages and coverdisks, but Acting Editor Andy Nuttall and team stood firm, delivering a bumper issue. It wasn’t without its price, tho: “So, it’s taken us ages longer than normal to write, the coverdisks nearly killed us, and getting in the finished version of SWOS for review was a nightmare.”
The fate of Commodore remained up in the air, with little news to be had. The only new development of interest being that US-based Creative Equipment International had put up a $1 million deposit as a first step towards an acquisition. Commodore UK’s team remained the main other contender.
Always hard to know if this was a sign of a slow news month, but two new lottery number picking applications were available from OnLine PD.
BT was to trial interactive TV in 2,500 homes in Colchester, promising on demand movies, grocery shopping, home banking and more. They also hoped to add pay to play gaming.
The interestingly named MPEG company were to bring a series of porn Video CDs to market that were compatible with digital video cart equipped CD32s. Titles included “Back to Melrose Place” and “Quantum Deep”.
A TV ad campaign that featured “robots gatecrashing scenes of fifties dancing and gaiety, along with the line ‘you can’t dance with broken legs’” was enough to get the “Rise of the Robots” commercial a ban from being shown during religious and kid’s programmes.
American retailer Microplay were to open a store in Birmingham offering customers the ability to exchange and sell games. It seems this practice had been frowned on by industry lawyers, so people were uncertain of how long it’d last.
Anco announced the next instalment in the Kick Off series, “Kick Off 3 - European Challenge” which would boast a bevy of new features, including teams playing in the style they’re known for.
Adventure gamers were in for a bit of a treat with budget label Kixx launching two new compilations, both priced at £29.99. The first included five classic LucasArts adventures: “The Secret of Monkey Island”, “Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade”, “Zak McKracken and the Alien Mindbenders”, “Loom” and “Maniac Mansion”. The second featured a series of Delphine games: “Flashback”, “Another World”, “Cruise for a Corpse”, “Operation Stealth” and “Future Wars”.
Chelsea Football Club had sued Commodore for £119,000, which they felt they were owed after they reached the 1994 FA Cup Final. Commodore reckoned they were being “extremely cheeky”, especially since the club had only provided a few tickets, having to pay for others.
“Exile” was set to get a bit of a make over for its re-release, targeting the AGA machines and CD32.
Team 17 had high hopes for their new game, “Worms”, due out in April for the 1200 and CD32. They also revealed “Pussies Galore”, a platformer involving - I think - rescuing kittens (unreleased).
The hugely anticipated “Frontier: First Encounters” got a few new screenshots… except they were from the PC version. Was that a bad omen for Amiga fans? (yes)
Apparently SDL’s “Critical Zone” CD32 bundle (console + 7 games) was flying off the shelves.
Psygnosis looked to clear out a load of old stock, selling around 50 titles for between £4.99 and £9.99.
“Rise of the Robots” CD32 was off to a strong start, claiming the number 2 best selling CD game spot (behind “Mega Race” for the Mega CD).
Media companies began to take some interest in some new fangled Internet thing.
There was to be a US only release of a Mortal Kombat album, with tracks based on each of the fighters.
Features #On the three coverdisks this month:
“Jungle Strike” Ocean (demo) “Battle Tanks” Magnetic Fields “Holiday Lemmings” Psygnosis “Super Skidmarks” Acid (demo) Getting the Work In Progress features this month were:
“The Chaos Engine 2” Bitmap Brothers/Renegade (with suitable moody photos of the lads) “Shadow Fighter” Gremlin “Pizza Tycoon” Microprose “Extractors” Millennium (unreleased) There was a look back at the games reviewed in 1994. Best score: “Theme Park” (92%). And worst? Psygnonsis’s “Last Action Hero” (8%).
PD games review:
“Erik” 77% “Beavis ’n’ Butthead Breaking the Lawn” 70% “Marbles” 90% “Clique Attack” 44% “Friday the 13th Part 2” 59% Notable Reviews # “Mortal Kombat II” Probe/Acclaim - 90% “The Amiga conversion is damn-near identical to the Mega Drive game, and what it lacks in animated backgrounds it more than makes up for with a plethora of deep-throated samples, some of which were sadly missing from the Mega Drive.” “Roadkill” Acid Software/Guidhall - 90% (CD32) “Don’t be fooled by the lack of complex gameplay, Roadkill is brilliant. Though basically nothing more than an overhead racing game with brass knobs on, it scores 100 percent in the atmosphere and overall feel department.” “Marvin’s Marvellous Adventure” Infernal Bytes Systems/21s Century - 82% (A1200) “Had Marvin been absolutely brilliantly designed then this would have been perfect, and certainly almost equalled the Mario games in terms of pure, unadulterated gaming fun.” (A good mate of mine and brilliant programmer coded this) “Dreamweb” Creative Reality/Empire - 85% (A1200) “Without the atmospherics there’s not a enough depth of either gameplay or characters in Dreamweb to hold your attention for long periods of time.” “The All New World of Lemmings” DMA Design/Psygnosis - 89% (A1200) “To be honest, though, I never found Lemmings 1 or 2 particularly easy or comfortable to control; so this all-new control system with a small number of huge icons that are easy to hit with the mouse are right up my fenêtre, as Matt would say.” “Sensible World of Soccer” Sensible Software/Renegadde - 90% “I’d hoped to give SWOS a higher mark, but would be lying if I said I’d been totally blown away by it. Still, don’t get me wrong, SWOS is absolutely fab; just don’t be surprised if it’s not quite as stunning as you’d hoped.” (Personally I strongly disagree with this - SWOS still stands as one of the greatest games ever made) “Whizz” Flair - 81% “Whizz, though, is faster than the first [Head over Heels], and prettier than the second [Crystal Castles] - and despite being a standard platformer at heart, the isometric perspective tricks your mind into thinking it’s playing something revolutionary.” “Sim City 2000” Maxis - 80% (A1200) “Surely this gane is the result of laziness on Maxis’ behalf. Come on guys, we want to see games that take advantage of the Amiga’s strengths, not direct ports from the PC.” “Pinball Illusions” Digital Illusions/21st Century - 91% (A1200) “And multiball… well, since I heard about Illusions I’ve been wondering how they’d do it, and the flip between lo- and hi-res modes works astonishingly well. Yes, my friends, Pinball’s back. And this time it’s brought its friends…” “Alien Breed: Tower Assault” Team 17 - 86% “I guess what you really want to know is whether Tower Assault more of the same, or something all fresh and sparkly. Well, you can paint me in creosote for sitting on the fence, but the truth is that it’s a bit of both.” Charts # “Cannon Fodder 2” Sensible Software/Virgin “Mortal Kombat II” Acclaim “Football Glory” Black Legend
title: This month in... The One '95

content:
News #While there was still no news on the fate of Commodore, the UK office was busy preparing for the World of Commodore show, which was to take place at the Wembley Exhibition Centre, December 9th through 11th. It was to be a “buying show” where the primary goal was for attendees to do a bit of shopping, but The One wondered if there’d be any Commodore kit left to purchase by then.
Anco’s next footie game would be “Fantasy Football Manager”, tho it seems like it was never released.
Retailer Silica released a new CD32 pack called “Critical Zone” with seven games bundled for £249.
There had been excitement at The One’s office upon receiving a review copy of “Sensible World of Soccer”, however they decided to hold off on publishing for a month as there were still a few features missing.
Vulcan Software were moving at quite a clip with the development of their Valhalla series. It took them a mere five months to finish “Valhalla: Before the War” which was due out in January.
Supermarkets would now be stocking the latest PD wares thanks to Wholesale Public Domain. They apparently handled distributing games from US devs like Apogee, id and Epic Mega Games.
SSI had been acquired by Mindscape for a cool £11.5 million. During the same week they also bought French developer Atreid Concept.
Meanwhile, CentreGold (US Gold’s parent company) had snapped up Core Design for “over £5 million”.
The UK government’s Monopolies and Mergers Commission had been asked to look into the way games were made and sold due to complaints it had received from parents, customers and retailers. It was unclear when the verdict would be announced, but it was expected to be a “not guilty”.
21st Century had just released the eagerly anticipated “Pinball Illusions”, the third entry in the series.
The One had their hopes up that Cryo would be bringing “Commander Blood” (a sequel to the baffling “Captain Blood”) to the Amiga (they didn’t).
The next submarine sim from Microprose was to be “Sub War 2050”.
Krisalis reckoned they had a Zelda competitor in development in the form of “Legend”. Hmm, not sure about that.
Production of Data Design’s “Zonked!” (which had been reviewed last issue) had stalled due to - and it seems this was serious - the game’s two programmers both breaking their arms.
“Frontier: First Encounters” had also been delayed, but for unknown reasons. It would not make it to the Amiga.
I don’t really know what this story means, but Nazrac “The Eliminator” was sponsoring a “Galactic tour” around the US and London to find the champion of Time Warner’s new arcade machine, “T-MEK”.
Sensi Soft’s Jon Hare accused Kompart of producing a Sensi Soccer “lookalike” with its “Football Glory”. He did have a point there.
Features #On this month’s two demo disks:
“Rise of the Robots” Mirage (demo) “Mortal Kombat II” Acclaim (demo) An interview with programmer John Twiddy.
Getting the in-depth Work in Progress this month:
“The Lion King” Virgin “Mighty Max” WJS Designs/Ocean (unreleased) “Mortal Kombat II” Probe/Acclaim “Sensible Golf” Sensible Software/Virgin Notable Reviews # “Cannon Fodder 2” Sensible Software/Virgin - 85% “There’s no arguing that the Cannon Fodder concept is a brilliant one, but as far as reviewing it as a sequel goes, I must say that I’m a bit disappointed.” “Jungle Strike” Hyperial/Ocean - 86% “Somehow the game doesn’t seem quite as threatening as Desert Strike, maybe because of the Gulf ‘thang’, and essentially for Desert vets it’s more of the same.“ “Premier Manager 3” Realms of Fantasy/Gremlin - 87% “It has to be said that Premier Manager 3 is the best the series will ever get. But I think Gremlin has added just as many bells and whistles to an otherwise plain game as it possibly can.” “PGA Euro Tour” The Dome/Ocean - 88% “Golf games stand or fall by their control method and PGA scores a hole-in-one. ‘Pars’ and ‘birdies’ are gettable, but consistency is a bit of a bugger to achieve and this, they tell me, is what makes golf an addictive game.” “Zeewolf” Binary Asylum - 80% “Game play-wise, Zeewolf is quite satisfying, with a ‘Desert Strike meets Apocalypse’ feeling, as you blow up buildings and rescue hapless folk.” “Super Stardust” Team 17 - 90% “… everything is exactly how it should be - traditional, uncomplicated gameplay wrapped up in eye-popping graphics. Most changes are purely cosmetic.” Charts # “Theme Park” EA “UFO” Microprose “Super Stardust” Team 17
title: This month in... The One '94

content:
News #Editor Simon Byron announced he was stepping down to work at a chip shop on the outskirts of Bognor: “I’ve decided that the life of a simple chippy is preferable to slogging my guts out on Britain’s least popular Amiga games magazine.” Andy Nuttall would be filling in as Acting Editor.
Frustrating times for Amiga journos and fans alike as there was still no news from Commodore on the future of the company.
I’m not sure if this was an indication on the dearth of news, but Impression’s had hired Daze Marketing to represent their upcoming titles: “Breach 3” (unreleased), “High Seas Trader”, “Lords of the Realm” and “Front Lines” (unreleased).
“Manga Mania” - apparently “the only British title to feature top Japanese Manga comic strips” - was getting a reboot/relaunch.
French conglomerate Chargeurs acquired a 24% stake of Ocean. The Manchester software house were looking to expand their operations in Europe and America, with new titles costing $250,000 to $2 million to develop.
Time Warner Interactive hoped that “Primal Rage” would be the next “Mortal Kombat”. As far as Amiga owners were concerned, the title would only be appearing the CD32 and would feature the new Cage ‘Total Immersion Audio’ system providing “stereo sound, serving to ‘punctuate the high-impact game play.’”
The price of Gepro’s “protective spectacles” was dropping to £24.99. They purported to completely block “harmful ultraviolet and electromagnetic rays”… hmm…
“All New World of Lemmings” was to be the next instalment in the series, introducing enemies while stripping the mechanics back to “a core of essential abilities for more instinctive playability.”
“Elite” co-creator, Ian Bell, was mulling over whether to take legal action against David Braben’s Frontier Developments for a slice of the “Frontier” pie. Braben felt he had already honoured his commitments.
Speaking of which, “Frontier” publisher GameTek were getting into the Video CD business with the launch of GameTek Cinema. First titles would include cult classics “Toxic Avenger” and “Class of Nuke ‘Em High”.
Trade body ELSPA was to publish a leaflet aimed at parents who were concerned about video games, called “A Parents’ Guide to Computer and Video Games”. It would include a look at the benefits of games, while tackling issues around addiction and violence.
Western Cairo officials shutdown all the arcades citing “moral decay”.
Virgin Megastore launched a radio station to play in all its stores across the country.
A range of coloured mice as on the way from Logitech.
LCL’s “Micro French” and Windshadow Software’ s “Making Music with Bertie Bunny” were two new educational titles.
There was sadly no elaboration as to the reasons why, but the Sega ports of “Rise of the Robots” were “pulled until Easter”, with 3DO and SNES versions also looking likely to join them. Never fear, since the Amiga was still on track to get the game in November.
Features #On this month’s two cover disks:
“Aladdin” Virgin (demo) (A1200 only) “Embryo” Black Legend (demo) Simon Byron met “Gamesmaster” host Dominic Diamond in a pub for an interview.
Games getting the in-depth Work in Progress treatment this month:
“Cannon Fodder 2” Sensible Software/Virgin “King of Thieves” Team 17 (unreleased) “Premier Manager 3” Realms of Fantasy/Gremlin “Mutant League Hockey” Catfish/Ocean “Powerdrive” Denton Designs/US Gold “Alien Breed: Tower Assault” Team 17 PD games reviewed:
“Chilly Chavez” 88% “Formula 1 Challenge” 81% “Introgash” 48% “Tony and Friends in Kelloggs Land” 93% “Nanofly” 50% Notable Reviews # “Aladdin” Virgin - 90% “It’s safe to say that this film conversion has captured the feel of its movie parent better than any licence before, which is unsurprising when you consider that Disney animators - arguably the best in the world - worked on the original Mega Drive graphics.” “Guardian” Acid Software - 88% “Fortunately, the high difficulty level isn’t too off-putting because the game is such a blimmin’ joy to play. Most of the time everything’s moving along nicely and the game only slows down when the screen’s really, really busy - which isn’t too often.” “Robinson’s Requiem” Silmarils - 81% “Robinson’s Requiem is a game where you have complete freedom over your environment. Every single item you pick up can be used in real life, and all you need to do is figure out which is most logical.” “Zonked!” Data Design/Psygnosis - 85% “Each of the 120 levels is cunningly designed to offer a subtly different challenge to the previous one, so sometimes you’ll find it’s a race against time, whereas others require a conservation of energy.” (unreleased?) “FIFA International Soccer” Visual Sciences/EA - 87% “When you’re playing, a crowd gathers mysteriously around your telly, because you could, quite literally, be watching Match of the Day. On the A500/600 it chugs along a bit, giving the impression of an ‘as a newt’ cameraman as the scrolling struggles to keep up with the play. But it’s very playable - and on an A1200 it’s faster than the console versions.” Charts # “Theme Park” Bullfrog/EA “On the Ball” Daze “Kick Off 3” Anco
title: This month in... The One '94

content:
News #After reporting that the saga of Commodore’s fate would be resolved “any day now” for the past few months, The One decided to quit guessing the timeline. In the latest twist, word arrived Commodore UK (lead by David Pleasance and Colin Proudfoot) were now the favourites with their proposal of a Management Buy Out, with Samsung apparently still keen. At the US head office Mehdi Ali was officially out.
The first bundle from Maxis would see “Sim City Classic”, “Sim Life” and “Sim Ant” packaged together for £34.99. Due for release at the same time were “A Train” and “Sim Earth”, which would be making their way to the Amiga, however it was unclear if their next two games (“SimTower” and “SimTown”) would.
Krisalis struck a deal with the PFA (Professional Footballers’ Association) to use the names of all their players and its “properties”. The first game to take advantage of this was to be “Player of the Year” and the software house re-affirmed its commitment to the Amiga. However, it doesn’t look like it saw a release.
A comic based on “Street Fighter II” was being launched by Manga Publishing.
The Live ‘94 show was returning to Earls Court in London from the 20th of September until the 25th.
Six of EA’s recent console games were getting ports to the Amiga courtesy of Ocean: “Jungle Strike”, “Skitchin’” (unreleased), “Shaq Fu”, “PGA Euro Golf”, “NHL 95” (unreleased) and “Mutant League Hockey” (unreleased). Ocean were also handling the SNES ports. Sales director Paul Patterson said: “We believe it’s important to send a clear message to the Amiga public that we will continue to support them with new and exciting products for so long as the market remains active.”
A survey of the British public by Mintel found that attitudes towards games had improved considerably over the previous few years.
The One poked some fun at Sensible Software with an old photo they had dug up of Chris Yates, Martin Galway and Jon Hare.
Mindscape was to show off Logitech’s new “Cyberman” control system in their racing game, “Mega Race” (unreleased). The “Cyberman” would provide “dimensional control” (whatever that is) and a “rattle and roll” effect.
Despite all the doom and gloom surrounding the Amiga, software sales were still strong with 21.6% vs 19.6% Mega Drive and PC 15%, though the lead was narrowing. The CD32 had slipped from almost 50% in April to 34.9% vs 44.6% PC.
Retailer Silica were introducing an extended 5 year warranty on Amigas.
The latest promotional campaign from MicroProse involved giving away a “long sleeved MicroProse sports shirt” to anyone buying a best-selling game at a number of high street chains.
Industry body ELPSA published a pocket guide for parents to try to assuage concerns about games. Meanwhile they decided to continue their stance against including full commercial games on mag coverdisks (Public Domain and shareware were fine).
Features #On this month’s two cover disks:
“Ruff ‘N’ Tumble” Renegade (demo) “Putty Squad” System 3 (demo) “Dragonstone” Core Design (demo) The One challenged a bunch of Amiga devs to the “1994 Brainiest Programmer in Britain Quiz” which posed questions like “What should register d0 contain if trying to open the graphics.library for an A1200-specific program?” and “What is the name of the extra chip resident in the Amiga CD32?”. The winner was Andrew Braybrook who scored 70%, just ahead of Shaun Southern and Mike Montgomery with 66%. Bringing up the rear was Julian Jameson (aka Jools) with an impressive 0%.
Andy Nuttall journeyed to Llandudno in Wales to interview the Magnetic Fields crew (Shaun Southern, Andrew Morris, Peter Liggett and Doug Braisby).
Getting the Work in Progress treatment this month were:
“Cyberwar” SCI Southampton/SCI (unreleased?) “All Terrain Racing” Team 17 “Football Glory” Croteam/Black Legend “Litil Divil” Gremlin Ireland/Gremlin Graphics “King of Thieves” Team 17 (unreleased) “The Big End” The Hidden/Supervision PD games reviewed:
“Zombie Apocalypse 2” 89% “Giddy 2” 85% “Demolition Mission” 74% “Black Dawn Special Edition ‘94” 73% “Fatal Mission 3” 90% Notable Previews # “Spherical Worlds” Croteam/Black Legend “Evil’s Doom” Croteam/Black Legend (unreleased) “Deathmasque” Apache “Super Loopz” Audiogenic Notable Reviews # “Universe” Core - 87% “Like ‘Flashback’, the lack of any background knowledge makes surviving in an alien environment pretty tough and the constant changing of pace ensures you’re always on your toes. Some of the links in the plot are a bit tenuous, and the solutions to a couple of the puzzles a little obscure, but the whole thing hangs together because it’s surprising.” “Pinkie” Millennium - 81% “Technically, Pinkie is brilliant. The graphics are gorgeous and full of character, with enough humorous animation to keep you amused for ages. There are an impressive amount of levels to plough through (something that - happily - seems to be becoming a Millennium trademark) and each of the worlds is satisfyingly different from the last.” “On the Ball” Ascon Sports/Daze - 90% “It’s rare to find a game that has both the depth of detail that most management game players go for AND the graphic quality to make it interesting enough to watch, so that you don’t just sit back and wait for text results.” “Ishar 3” Silmarils/Daze - 86% “Ishar 3 is an improvement over its prequels, but it still suffers slightly from the ‘wandering’ syndrome, so that the chances are if you can’t find what you’re looking for quickly, you’ll give up altogether. If you do persevere, though, you’ll discover something of a challenge - and that, above anything else, is what RPG afficionados [sic] are after.” “The Clue” Neo/Black Legend - 88% “The learning curve is spot-on, and you’ll soon get used to the different aspects of planning and strategy, not to mention making things difficult for Johnny Pig (you mean the police, yes? - Simon). The best part is the planning (which can be saved and re-run to check fine details) and the going into the burglary, running the plan, and sitting back while your outfit does its best to make you a fortune!” Charts # “Kick Off 3” Anco “Sensible Soccer International” Sensible Software/Renegade “World Cup Year ‘94” Empire
title: This month in... The One '94

content:
News #While Commodore was still without a buyer, word leaked that the company leading the pack was in fact Samsung who were looking to gain more of a foothold in the European market. It seemed everything was hanging on that deal.
Dominik Diamond was rumoured to be returning to “Gamesmaster”.
A report from Mintel showed that the UK games industry contracted by 4% last year. The market value in 1993 was £670 million compared to £700 million in 1992. One theory was falling software prices.
Music giant BMG announced they were making a move into games.
Team 17 had a busy few months ahead with planned releases of “Super Stardust”, “Overdrive”, “Alien Breed 2: Tower Assault”, “All Terrain Racing” and “King of Thieves”. The latter was particularly interesting as it was being developed by Rico Holmes and Andreas Tadic of “Alien Breed” fame, though it never saw a release.
Commodore’s schedule for the months leading up to Christmas showed they hoped to have 423 titles out for the CD32, almost double from what it was at this point (197). While that sounds impressive, it was largely made up of CD-i video discs and old CDTV “gardening hits and karaoke”.
Blockbuster coughed up £135 million to buy out Virgin Interactive Entertainment.
The biggest consumer entertainment show in the UK, Live ‘94, was to take place at Earls Court from September 20th to 25th. Around 200,000 visitors were expected.
Game industry body ELPSA launched three raids on pirates to recover 500 CDs of software in a haul apparently valued at £10 million.
It hadn’t been long since the release of “Frontier”, but “The First Encounter” - standalone followup - was due for release in October and promised a number of significant improvements (particularly “less bugs”). While it was released for PC, it wouldn’t end up gracing the Amiga.
Distributor ZCL announced a series of peripherals. There was a CD drive for the A1200 costing £199.99 and an adapter for the CD32 allowing the user to connect a keyboard and floppy drive. They also had “two new types of storage card” delivering between 20mb and 340mb capacity.
Despite losing deals with LucasArts, SSI and Novalogic, US Gold were bullish about their prospects as they opened a new development office in Oxford called Silicon Dreams. Apparently LucasArts games had only made up 3% of their total sales.
Software house Zeppelin was snapped up by US publisher Merit Software for a £2.2 million.
After months of speculation, 20th Century Fox opened a games division which would release its first title “Pagemaster” in November (which would be developed by Probe). Seems it only made it out on PC and handhelds.
UK high street retailer Currys was set to close 80 town centre stores with 20 more likely to follow as the economic downtown took hold. Boots had also reported game sales had dropped by a third during the first quarter of the year.
Sales chart company Gallup were to increase the number of retailers contributing to the numbers to 3250, up from 2000.
Microvalue’s “Soccer Superstars” would feature the logo of sports company Mitre in a licensing deal.
Features #On this month’s two cover disks:
“Kid Chaos” Ocean (demo) “Drelbs” Simon Chin (PD) “Wild Cup Soccer” Millennium (demo) “Vital Light” Millennium (demo) An interview with Paul Carrington and Lisa Tunnah who had formed Vulcan Software and recently released their first game, “Valhalla”, after a mere 5 months of development time.
The One called out software publishers and developers for talking guff about how great their upcoming games were going to be (which then turned out to be naff), in an article titled “Liars!”.
Andrew Braybrook highlighted some games which he reckoned had pushed the Amiga’s technical capabilities. They were:
“Elfmania” Renegade “Stardust” Daze Marketing “Galactic” Satvros Fasoulas “Turrican 1 & 2” Factor 5/Rainbow Arts “Agony” Psygnosis Getting the in-depth Work in Progress treatment this month:
“Nova Storm” Psygnosis (unreleased) “Simon the Sorcerer 2” Adventuresoft “King Pin” Team 17 The One checked in on where “Rise of the Robots” and “Zeewolf” - two games “stuck in development hell” - were at.
The final instalment of the “Sensible World of Soccer” dev diary and Jon Hare stopped by the mag for a chat.
Public Domain games reviewed:
“Drelbs” 84% “Glaxo” 79% “Obliteratives” 82% “Mucus” 52% “Better Dead than Alien” 81% Speaking of Public Domain games, there was a feature on PD coin op clones which included:
“Bob’s Garden” (“Mr Do”) “Donkey Kong” (er, no guesses) “Digger” (“Dig Dug”) “Hemroids” (“Asteroids”) “Gorf” (“Gorf”) “Mouthman” (“Pacman”) “Croak” (“Frogger”) Notable Previews # “Dawn Patrol” Empire “Planet Football” Infogrames (unreleased?) “Fields of Glory” Microprose “Operation G2” Psygnosis (unreleased) Notable Reviews # “Ruff ‘N’ Tumble” Wunderkind/Renegade - 91% “Everything about it hangs together brilliantly; the graphic style is perfect, the gameplay finely-tuned, and the pumping soundtrack requires two huge speakers and sympathetic neighbours to show it at its best. Yes, I know it’s a bit embarrassing, and I’m sure you’re aware of how much I like to moan, but Ruff ’n’ Tumble really is the apex of platform pleasure.” “Wild Cup Soccer” Teque/Millennium - 81% “I enjoyed Wild Cup Soccer - in two-player mode, anyway. Charging around, mashing the opposition in a variety of satisfyingly gory and violent ways, is a right hoot and no mistaking.” “Vital Light” Efecto Caos/Millennium - 81% “… the early levels are tediously easy and the whole thing smacks of a poor man’s Tetris. Dig a bit deeper, though, and you discover that the game - despite its aesthetics - is a shoot-’em-up at heart, but one which requires as much forward planning as Tetris, Klax and their ilk.” “Putty Squad” System 3 - 90% “All of the things that let Putty down first time round have been improved a thousand times over, with major gameplay improvements, excellent level layouts, and some really good toys to get your teeth into.” (this didn’t see a release until 2013) “Kid Chaos” Magnetic Fields/Ocean - 87% “What we have is a lightning-fast platformer, running easily as quickly as Sonic on the Mega Drive, and there’s even an impressive number of enemies in there too. Add to that the most layers of parallax scrolling that we’ve seen since Lionheart, a thumping soundtrack and a range of spot-on sound effect, and you’re looking at a very impressive game.” Charts # “Kick Off 2” Anco “Sensible Soccer International” Renegade “World Cup Year ‘94” Empire
title: This month in... The One '94

content:
News #The fate of Commodore UK was close to becoming a bit clearer with an announcement regarding a new owner was due “any day now”. The “most solid” information pointed to a “Far-Eastern” company, with Acer, Samsung and Goldstar all rumoured to be in the running. While the UK office had continued trading, they weren’t receiving any new units to sell which meant they had to make do with whatever stock they had in their warehouses. The One was putting on a brave face: “It’s pretty unthinkable that a company which can sell 150,000 machines at £299 each in a year (the Amiga 1200, in other words) will be simply wiped out. Expect good news soon.” Hmm yeah.
The One took a look at just how Commodore found itself in this grim situation.
Glasgow based Amiga user group 24-bit Club were holding a competition for art created on the Amiga, with prizes totalling £5,000 to be won.
Amiga distributor Silica had slashed the price of a A4000 030 with 214mb hard drive by £200 (down to £999). The 540mb model would set you back £1299.
NewTek was to sell “Lightwave” by itself for the first time (rather than bundled with their Video Toaster). The expected cost was to be around £600.
BSkyB’s videogame show “Head to Head” (hosted by Violet Berlin) was to get a “3D version” requiring 3D glasses.
The Golden Joysticks were held, with Virgin taking “Best Software House”, “Cannon Fodder” “Best Original Computer Game”, Sensible Software “Best Computer Programmer” and “TFX” “Best Computer Simulation”. Acclaim also picked up an award for “services to the industry”. The night was hosted by “zany, madcap Radio 1 DJ, Steve Wright”.
Somewhat bizarrely, Oxford based Data Business were producing what looked like erotic mouse pads.
Game industry trade body ELSPA were considering relaxing their rules on covermounted games. Giving away whole (commercial) games was a no-no, but opinions were starting to shift with regards to older back catalogue titles. I’m curious as to when the original rules came into place since mags went to town with that kind of thing in the late 80s.
Despite the Commodore drama, Amiga software sales continued to be strong. They accounted for 21% of all games sold in the UK, slightly less than the Mega Drive, but double that of SNES and PC. It was a 1.5% rise on the previous month. CD32 crept up to 2.5% and was still fair ahead of the other CD platforms.
Team 17 were staying loyal to the Amiga with a whopping 12 CD32 games in development. Their recently released “Arcade Pool” raced to #1 in the charts, and they rejected thoughts of licensing console conversions out (doesn’t mean they wouldn’t do them in house, of course).
Sensible Software and Renegade were about to release “Sensible Soccer International Edition” which was all up to date for the World Cup and would sport a few new features such as yellow and red cards.
Gepro claimed their glasses would provide 99% protection against “electromagnetic radiation” which reducing eyestrain and combatting drowsiness. Hmm.
“Euroscene 1” was a CD compilation from Almathera featuring “game sequences, art, music and graphics demos by the 10,000 Amiga programmers who contribute to the Amiga demo scene.”
IBM had developed a new CD format which would be able to store “12 hours of music or several movies”. They had figured out a way to effectively stack multiple layers onto a single disc. The downside being that existing CD players would not be able to read them…
Virgin opened 6 new Megastores. The One was supportive of the move given that they’d be carrying Amigas as well as those pesky consoles which other chains had started to sell exclusively.
Interplay V1.0 from Optonica was a CDrrom authoring system for Amigas.
Features #On this month’s two coverdisks:
“Sensible Soccer International Edition” Sensible Software (demo) “Out to Lunch” Mindscape (demo) “Empire Soccer” Empire (demo) “Quik” Titus (demo) An interview with Graftgold’s Andrew Braybrook, Jose Doran, Kevin Holloway and Steve Wilkins to coincide with the release of their new footie game, “Empire Soccer”.
The One’s interpretation of the history of the Amiga in a series of comic pane style photos.
A selection of software houses gave their thoughts on their early Amiga titles, and The One rated their progression over the years.
A collection of “fan-tastic” Amiga related facts which may or may not have been mainly bollocks.
Gary Penn provided a rundown of his essential Amiga games and had a good rant about how quality games were coming to an end on the machine as developers flocked to more lucrative platforms.
Getting the in depth Work In Progress treatment:
“FIFA International Soccer” Electronic Arts “Kid Vicious” Magnetic Fields/Ocean “Top Gear 3” Gremlin (unreleased?) “Wild Cup Soccer” Millennium The Sensible World of Soccer dev diary reached its fifth instalment, which began with journo Matt Broughton getting somewhat desperate over not having anything to write about. Thankfully he finally got Jon Hare on the phone who talked in great detail about their recent work on the transfer market and the complexities of calculating a player’s form.
PD games reviewed:
“Temporal Misplacement” 37% “Overlander” 88% “World Darts Champion” 69% “Rob’s Games” 90% “Ant War” 59% Notable Previews # “World Cup Soccer Star” Soccer Star/Kompart “Soccer Stars” Flair “Psycho Pinball” Codemasters (unreleased) Notable Reviews # “Out to Lunch” Mindscape - 90% “I like it. A lot, in fact - Mindscape has come up with one of the simplest and most addictive platformers for ages. I could rattle out the age-old cliches like ‘it takes a minute to learn but a life-time to master’ or ‘simply brilliant and brilliantly simple’ (or something like that), but I won’t. Because I just have.” “Quik” Titus - 80% “At best Quik is a very fast (quick?) platformer, with sparsely-populated levels and loads of open space to gambol in, but it loses points because the action stays the same despite a number of different graphical changes.” “Banshee” Core Design - 89% “The game’s a great roller-coaster ride to hell, and it takes every ounce of concentration to keep the cool-hand and clear head even for the most hardened game player.” Charts # “Arcade Pool” Team 17 “Beneath a Steel Sky” Revolution/Virgin “Skidmarks” Acid
title: This month in... The One '94

content:
News #News broke as the mag went to press that Commodore worldwide had basically filed for administration in the Bahamas, where the company was registered. Just what this meant was unclear, but things did not look good. It wasn’t terribly surprising considering the losses the company had posted over the last couple of years, though Commodore UK had performed well. While this move was obviously concerning, The One were confident that the continued popularity of the Amiga would mean a positive outcome one way or another.
The winners of the ECTS awards were announced with “Doom” dominating, picking up “Computer Game of the Year” and “Overall Game of the Year”. Viewers of BBC kids TV show “Alive and Kicking” chose “Frontier” for their award, “Rebel Assault” won “Best CD Game” and “Syndicate” “Most Original Game”. Perhaps the most galling win as far as Amiga fans were concerned was that of the Atari Jaguar over the CD32 for “Best Hardware”.
Mersyside-base Spectacular Graphics had produced a coin-op cabinet for the arcades that could house a CD32.
BT joined the games industry’s governing body ELPSA as they continued their push towards delivering games and movies over their network. While it was clear this would be some way off for the customers, they were pumping billions of pounds into their efforts and had setup an experiment with 70 employees in Ipswich. Oracle were providing their “Massively Parallel Processing” tech which would allow BT to keep just one digitised copy of game while serving thousands of players.
The CD32 continued to dominate CD software sales and several new titles were announced: “Rise of the Robots”, “Cyberwar” (not released?), “Empire Soccer” and “Sim City 2000”.
The World of Commodore show was making a comeback, slightly re-branded as World of Amiga and would take place at Wembley in November.
The CD sales figures put the CD32 at a 55.6% market share, PC 24.2%, Mega CD 18.3% and CD-i 1.1%.
Team 17 were about to release “Alien Breed II: Tower Assault” on floppy as well as a CD32 enhanced “Alien Breed II”. Other titles in development were an arcade strategy game called “King of Thieves” and a 10-pin bowling game.
The One were launching a club.. maybe? Or maybe it was just an excuse to explain away typos as coded messages.
Another month, another new CD32 bundle from Commodore. The Spectacular Voyage pack featured six games: “Microcosm”, “The Chaos Engine”, “Wing Commander”, “Dangerous Streets”, “Diggers” and “Oscar”. The price was £249.99.
“P.I.D.” (Private Investigator Dollarlaly) was to be a racing game from Terramarque in the “Spy Hunter”/“APB” vein. It was unreleased.
Tucked away in a corner of Commodore’s ECTS stand was a prototype CD drive for the A1200 which caused a bit of a stir. However, there were no concrete plans for selling it at that point in time. David Pleasance felt the lack of MPEG video playback would reduce its appeal so they would need to find a compelling price point.
Developer Stellar Genesis Agency were working on CD strategy game “Space Academy” for Mindscape (unreleased?).
Speaking of Mindscape… they had just been bought by media giant Pearson for a cool £310 million. Pearson owned the likes of Thames TV, the Financial Times and Penguin Books.
POSH Marketing had developed a touchscreen for the CD32 which would find its way into information access terminals like those found at airports.
The Computer Graphics Expo was to take place at Wembley in November.
New Tek’s Video Toaster was finally going to get a UK release. It wouldn’t come cheap, mind you, as the software, A4000 and NTSC -> PAL converter would total around £12,000. There was also a brief mention of Commodore’s latest machine, the A4000 tower ( the “most powerful Amiga ever”) for £2999.99.
Dr Julia Rutkowska told the British Psychological Society that computer games can increase sociability rather than the commonly perceived idea that they resulted in loners.
It looked like Virgin Interactive Entertainment was being fought over by PolyGram and Disney. VIE was about to be listed on the US stock exchange and was part owned by Blockbuster Video… who PolyGram had a majority stake in. Meanwhile the software house had a close relationship with Disney. At any rate, between that and the share flotation it was expected that Virgin would be getting a serious cash injection.
Computer store chain Silica (described as “the Amiga’s most loyal high street supporter”) were to open 20 new shops.
Pinball was to meet RPGs in “Ultimate Pinball Quest” from Infogrammes.
Peter Molyneux was to make an appearance at Level One in London to show off “Theme Park”.
A sequel to Sensible Software’s “Canon Fodder” was in the works, but it was early days (one level set in the desert) and they hadn’t decided on a name but were determined it wouldn’t be called “Cannon Fodder 2”.
Features #On this month’s two cover disks:
“Armour-Geddon 2” Psygnosis (demo) “Digger” “Touch ‘N’ Go” “Gulp” ICE (demo) “Kung Fu Charlies” A big report on all the Amiga related announcements and gossip at ECTS.
An interview with Tony Bickley, a senior producer at US Gold, discussing the upcoming “World Cup ‘94”.
Getting the in depth Work in Progress treatment this month:
“Ruff ‘n’ Tumble” Renegade “Kick Off 3” Anco “Dragonstone” Core Design “Marvin’s Marvellous Adventure” Infernal Bytes “Super Stardust” Bloodhouse “Valhalla and the Lord of Infinity” Vulcan (a little odd this got a preview and a review in the same issue, but apparently the game was in development right up until the deadline) I didn’t actually realise this regular feature was a development diary of “Sensible World of Soccer” until its fourth installment in this issue
I thought it was a weirdly long drawn out series of interviews with Sensi. At any rate, the main thing this month was they had implemented The Season mode… that and Jon and Chris Chapman flew to LA to meet with Virgin and, er, go to Disneyland. In this month’s PD Zone:
“High Octane” “Relics of Deldroneye” “Touch ‘N’ Go” “Sploggy” “Fortress” Notable Previews # “Embryo” Black Legend/Croteam “On the Ball” Ascon/Daze “Space Checkers” Black Legend/Croteam (unreleased) Notable Reviews # “Elfmania” Terramarque/Renegade - 91% “Elfmania makes all other beat ‘em-ups looks like out-dated crap and will hopefully prevent other software companies even dreaming about releasing complete rubbish like ‘Dangerous Streets’ on any format.” “Valhalla: The Lord of Infinity” Vulcan - 81% “The speech… well, it talks, which is impressive and innovative, but after a few hours the main character’s whiny voice gets annoying. He’s got a relatively huge vocabulary, but there’s only so many times you can hear him say ‘I’m scared,’ without wishing there was an option to listen to only the important points.” “Bump ‘N’ Burn” Grandslam - 90% “So here we have, in essence, Super MarioKart - and bloody good it is too! If you’re familiar with the SNES game I’ve mentioned, you’ll already be aware of the simple fun to be had from this sort of racing game, but you really have to play ‘Bump ‘N’ Burn’ to appreciate just how addictive it is, especially when the producers have got the CPU intelligence just right (which I’m glad to announce, Grandslam has done here).” “Tactical Manager” Talking Birds/Kompart UK - 80% “Very seldom, though, did I find myself having fun, and that - call me picky - is how I judge a game. For me, TM is too realistic; there are just too many stats for each player, which you must read and digest if you want to succeed.” “Benefactor” Digital Illusions/Psygnosis - 85% “It’s got a strange appeal, perhaps even more so than Lemmings had - partly because the solutions to most of the early levels are entirely obvious, but they rely on some joystick trickery as well as a quick imagination to complete.” “Sierra Soccer: World Challenge Edition” Sierra - 83% “Unlike many recent releases, Sierra Soccer has managed to take all the good features from the best footy games around and re-present them in such a way that the game stands up in its own right.” “James Pond 3: Operation Starfi5h” Millennium - 90% “If I told you that Operation Starfi5h was quite unlike any other Amiga platform game, I wouldn’t be lying, it’s huge. No really, it’s very huge… and bloody fast.”
title: This month in... The One '94

content:
News #Andy Nuttall (aka “Nutts”) joined the mag as Deputy Editor after having done five months hard time at ST Format.
Third time’s the charm - or so Commodore hoped with its third CD32 bundle since launch. The Voyage pack included “Microcosm” and “The Chaos Engine”, plus four games from the two existing bundles while stocks lasted, all for £299.99.
Codemasters were bringing “Captain Dynamo” and the “Dizzy CD Collection” to the CD32. The latter would contain ten games on one CD and cost £21.99. They were contemplating of also releasing “Micro Machines” and more on the console if sales were up to scratch.
ESP reckoned their “Oracle Racing System” software could predict winning race horses when the latest details were fed into its database. It was available via mail order for a cool £99.95
“Lemmings for Breakfast” was a promotional campaign by Boots, WH Smith, Psygnosis and The Big Breakfast TV show which would see the high street stores slashing the prices of the “Lemmings” releases.
A monitor shortage that had plagued Commodore after Philips pulled out of the Amiga monitor shortage just before Christmas looked to be at an end with ZCL supplying the Microvitec Pro Graphics Multi Sync. Stocks of 1084s looked to have been replenished as well.
It seemed last month’s review of “Bubble ‘n’ Squeak” featured the wrong verdict panel, so The One provided the correct one. (Final score of 87%)
Virgin acquired a 25% stake in point and click specialist Revolution Software in order to take on LucasArts and Sierra On-Line.
The success of “Microcosm” seemed to take Psygnosis a little by surprise as stocks ran out. Not only was it the number on CD32 title, but by mid March the CD32 had already captured 44% of CD software sales.
As reported last month, Domark’s distribution manager Russell Ferrier was working with Middlesex University to establish a game design degree. Interestingly, applicants would be financed by software houses.
Audiogenic got the rights to use the Wembley (as in, the stadium) name and were planning to release “Wembley Rugby League” and “Wembley International Soccer”.
Experts were skeptical of the hype over the “information superhighway” and predicted that it’d be quite some time before consumers would be shopping, banking, watching TV, downloading games and so on over “a single cable into the living room”. Apparently 77% of people had never used a fax, and 66% hadn’t used a PC. That latter stat seems quite remarkable.
There was a story about how Tony Cooper met his fiancé Janette in Portsmouth after he repaired her printer… They were both Amiga fans which, I guess, is why it made the news page.
Vulcan claimed their new game, “Valhalla and the Lord of the Infinity”, was the “first ever speech adventure” as it featured a vocabulary of over 1,000 words. It would come on at least five disks but they promised no disk swapping during levels.
Castle Communications were bullish about the potential for Video CDs and announced three titles for release this month: “Pavarotti Nessus Dorma”, “The History of Aviation” and “Dinosaurs Myth and Reality”.
Features #Three disks graced this month’s cover featuring:
“Mr Nutz” Ocean (demo) “Ouch” PD “Clockwiser” Rasputin (demo) “Pugsy” Psygnosis (demo) “Tanx ‘n’ Stuff” PD “Xmas Time” PD “Banshee” Core Design (demo) “Smidge” PD “Waggle O Mania 2” Team 17 Matt Broughton spent a day out filming with the crew and presenters of BBC2’s new computer show, “The Net”. Each episode would include a segment called “Net Attack” which focused on games and was produced by Dan Clapson who, it turned out, had coded the Amiga and ST ports of “Chip’s Challenge” amongst others.
A snarky feature giving readers a peak at what would happen if the mag printed reader reviews. Basically all scores were 100% and the summaries barely coherent.
An interview with Arcane Software Developments who had produced the “Powermonger”, “Populous 2” and “Birds of Prey” intros before moving onto “Darkmere” and the upcoming “Turbo Trax”.
Games getting the in-depth Work in Progress treatment this month:
“Impossible Mission 2025” Microprose “Hard Core” Digital Illusions/Psygnosis (unreleased) “Sim City 2000” Maxis “Overlord” Rowan Software/Virgin “Putty Squad” System 3 (unreleased until 2013) “Mr Magoo” Millenium (unreleased) Andy Nuttall paid the Sensi lads a visit in what was part 3 of The One’s series of interviews with them. The main topics discussed were the soon-to-be- released “Sensible Soccer v1.2 - International Edition” and the highly anticipated “proper” follow up, “Sensible World of Soccer”.
PD Zone titled covered in this month:
“Smidge” 90% “Karate Master” 80% “Task Force” 69% “Splodge” 69% “Xmas Time” 68% “Punters” 87% “Digger” 85% The issue closed with a rather entertaining “Next Month” page, done in the style of TV listings. Someone definitely had fun with this one.
Notable Previews # “Empire Football” Empire “Tactical Manager” Black Legend “D-Day The Beginning of the End” Impressiions “Lords of the Realm” Impressions Notable Reviews # “K240” Gremlin - 90% “Not since Dune 2 have we been treated to such a great strategy game, designed in the mould of Populous but taking the whole idea beyond the stars and, er, into asteroids.” “Armour-Geddon II” Psygnosis - 86% “So, if you like to pick up a game and play it immediately, leave Armour-Geddon II well alone. The manual, for example, takes a good half-hour to read, while the game itself needs much longer to get to grips with.” “Arcade Pool” Team 17 - 82% “Obviously there’s no way that Team 17’s top-down simulation could ever beat the technical standards set by the follow-up to Jimmy White’s Whirlwind Snooker, but I reckon there’s room for more than one decent pool simulation and if you feel the same way this could be right up your street.” “Kings Quest VI” Revolution/Sierra OnLine - 84% “Though KOVI is not quite up to the standard of Simon The Sorceror (American spelling, not mine) or Beneath a Steel Sky, it certainly has as much to offer as far as depth and problem solving goes.” “Ultimate Body Blows” Team 17 - 81% “Another plus is that the CD32 controllers make individual moves and special moves easier to carry out, and you also get the feeling that the designers were more comfortable with the extra buttons. So that means this is a better system to run Body Blows on.” “Apocalypse” Miracle Games/Virgin - 81% “Although Apocalypse does its best to put you off from the start with what appear to be unfairly-tough enemy attack patterns, with perseverance it’s apparent that everything happens for a reason.”
title: This month in... The One '94

content:
When I made the decision to join Magic Leap back at the start of 2013, I told my friends that I had no idea where it was going to lead, but I knew it would be a ride… and that it was.
It’s two weeks to the day that myself, my team here in NZ and over 1,000 of my workmates at offices across the world were laid off. Well, technically those of us in NZ entered into a “consultation” period of a few days as mandated by NZ law, but that ended on Monday with all of us being made redundant. It was a sad end to what had been an intense (in good and bad ways) but incredible 7.5 years for me.
I was - to my knowledge - the first games industry person to join the company when the headcount was 20-ish. While my primary focus was on creating Mixed Reality games/experiences, I was very fortunate to get to work closely with people on teams throughout the company from all manner of fields, software and hardware. Headpose, world reconstruction, hand tracking, eye tracking, 6dof totems, object recognition, optics, audio algorithms, OS, SDK, deep learning.. the list goes on. I even maintained our prototype devices, manually re- calibrating and performing occasional surgery on them. It was all absolutely fascinating.
My team were always the first to take bleeding edge in-development platform features and integrate them into our experiences to help iron out issues and guide the API design. We worked with pretty much every device revision, from bare boards through to final wearables. While this was a challenging endeavour it was hugely beneficial to the platform and the company as whole.
As for the games we created, we knew right from the very start that Mixed Reality was going to provide some significant new challenges. The primary one being that every user/player will have a unique experience since we merge virtual content with the real world. The implications of this are huge and impacts everything from AI and navigation, through to UX (where to place interactive objects and what does that interaction even look like), physics, sound design and more. All of our systems had to be designed with these challenges in mind. “Invaders” pushed the platform further than any other experience.
There’s so much more I could ramble on about - it was 7.5 years spent working with some of the smartest, most talented people on the planet. I learned so much and am immensely proud of what we achieved. I really hope the things we were working on see the light of day - they were awesome and very, very fun.
Make no bones about it, AR/MR is going to be huge - it will change everything. And there are suddenly a lot of brilliant people on the job market now who’ve been working on & living with this future tech and its implications for years… just sayin'.
title: Well, that was quite a ride

content:
News #Contrary to last month’s news, while ex-The One editor David Upchurch had been assigned to a new mag, it was to EMAP’s latest launch, PC Games, and not a reboot of Sinclair User… which made a little more sense.
Ocean struck a deal with Virgin to release twelve of its games on Hit Squad, their budget label. The lineup included “Cannon Fodder”, “Dune”, “Dune 2”, “Jimmy White’s Whirlwind Snooker”, “Archer Maclean’s Pool”, “Realms”, “Legend of Kyrandia”, “Supremacy”, “KGB”, “Reach for the Skies”, “Shuttle” and “Lure of the Temptress”. Ocean expected to sell 200,000 copies between them.
Edge magazine won “Magazine of the Year” (who decided that was not specified).
“Darkstone” was to follow “Darkmere” from Core Design, though apparently the two were not related… which is very odd as they share so many similarities.
Seven titles had been crammed into Commodore’s latest A1200 bundle: “Brian the Lion”, “Total Carnage”, “Zool 2”, “Digita Wordsworth 2.0”, “Digita Print Manager”, “Day by Day” and “Personal Paint 2.0”. Known as the “Computer Combat” pack, it would cost £349.99.
Dutch demo coders Team Hoi were to have their puzzler “Clockwiser” published by Rasputin. The software house had also lined up “Harold the Hairy Hermit” which was to feature “a totally unique sprite”. Hmm. It was not released.
Daze Marketing were flogging copies of “Ishar” and “Transartica” for £4.99 in order to drum up interest in the upcoming “Ishar 3” and “Robinson’s Requiem”.
Commodore kicked off a new initiative called ACE (Amiga Centres of Excellence) to highlight the ways the Amiga could help “pro” users.. The first location had already opened in Wales.
It’s easy to look back on the CD32 as a failure (which it was), but sales had been promising as it managed to capture 38.6% of the CD software market, ahead of PC CD-Rom (31.3%), Mega CD (27.6%) and the CD-i (1.8%). There were a bunch of big name releases on the way, not to mention the the hotly anticipated Video CD module (delayed due to “technical hitches” at manufacturers and, apparently, “nasty blizzards” at Commodore’s US HQ). Meanwhile the Jaguar and 3DO were difficult to find in shops… what could possibly go wrong?
The father of Domark boss Dominic Wheatley had written a Victorian detective book which had become the basis of a new who-dunnit for the CD32: “Herewith the Clues”.
The impending invasion of the games industry by Hollywood companies had been feared for some time, and things got a little more real with MCA/Universal buying a stake in Interplay.
News arrived that Team 17 had abandoned plans for “Alien Breed 3D” due to the release of some game called “Doom”, which apparently was a “startling shoot-em-up in the same vein”. The Alien Breed line would continue, though, in the form of “Alien Breed: Tower Assault”. (Maybe this was an April Fool’s?)
High street chains Our Price and Virgin Retail were to merge… except they were already both owned by WH Smith, so this seemed to be more a ploy to boost Our Price’s offerings using Virgin’s experience.
“Switchquiz” was a new pub quiz style game from Switchsoft with the unique selling point that it came with two or four handheld modules which plugged into the parallel port. Think “Buzz!” for the PS3, but ten years earlier.
The One recommended readers check out a fanzine called “Computer and Console Guide” by Nathan White.
There was a snarky note about Impact Magazines shuttering “Amiga Force” (or, “Amiga Farce”, as they referred to it).
Team 17 were looking to provide proper pub ambience with the release of “Arcade Pool” for the CD32 by taking a DAT tape with them on drinking sesh and recording forty mins of pub banter/sounds.
The ECTS Awards nominees had been announced, with Sensible Software in the running for Developer of the Year.
Console games “Pac Attack” and “Metal Marines” looked to be getting Amiga ports (‘cept they didn’t).
Thalion were still insisting that a “super enhanced” version of “Lionheart” was on the way for the CD32.
The One teased news of “at least 5 console conversions” coming to the Amiga, but it seemed the deal hadn’t quite been signed off on yet.
Features #On this month’s two cover disks:
“Heimdall 2” demo - Core Design “Parattack” “Bump ‘n’ Burn” demo - Grandslam “Cookie” There was a rather silly “interview” with a (fictional) software pirate who was repenting his evil ways.
Games getting in depth Work In Progress coverage in this issue were:
“Flight of the Amazon Queen” Interactive Binary Illusions/Renegade “Banshee” Core “Kult of Speed” Electronic Arts (unreleased) “Club Football - The Manager” Teque London/Imagine Home Entertainment Part 2 of the big feature on Sensible Software. The scoop this month was that “Sensible World of Soccer” had been pushed back to the start of the season in August, but to fill the void there’d be a world championship edition of “Sensible Soccer” to coincide with the World Cup.
In this month’s PD Zone:
